comment.author: 7768849@N05
comment._content: What a dramatic photo! The sheer scale of material mining is awesome. I found a historic description from the Institution of Mining Engineers (Great Britain). - 1903 - Technology & Engineering books.google.com/books?id=ufUQAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA675&l... Looks like the quarries near Carrick-on-Suir provided a lot of slate for roofing today www.killoranslate.ie/about-killoran-slate.php I imagine it was important building material for fencing, buildings, roads, etc. in the past as well, and I would imagine a lot of it being exported too. Some geological info on quarries in the vicinity www.gsi.ie/NR/rdonlyres/B8AACB00-8FD9-424D-A659-122E183F9... *see page 9 Perhaps others can shed more light? Fantastic photo, thank you for sharing!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Given Mr. Evans' address at Inchanaglogh, I think this 25" map link is probably the mine shown in the photo, the only one I see locally with a little tramway in it. It's flooded now, just a lake on the modern maps.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Think you're absolutely right, Niall, and still quite close to Carrick-on-Suir which it said on our catalogue record. Amending on our map now.

How beautiful is that map? The 25" inches are works of art in themselves!
